results.title: Girl groups: the story of a sound
results.creator_credit: Delilah Films, Stephanie Bennett and Steve Alpert
results.brief_description: Traces the story of the dream girls, punctuating over 25 of their greatest hits with fascinating insights into what went on behind the scenes. Highlighted by rare original footage of the groups performing their hits. Includes : The Chantels, The Shirelles, The Shangri-las, Little Eva, The Supremes and more.

results.title: Girl 6 = Girl six
results.creator_credit: 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks, Fox Searchlight Pictures and Spike Lee
results.brief_description: Theresa Randle is an attractive and talented actress but her inability to find acting work leads her to get a job working as a sex-phone operator. Initially suspicious, if intrigued, by the agency she works for, she finds that her work leads to her gaining empowerment over herself and her sexuality. Spike Lee’s “Girl 6” stands as one of his most under-rated films. A clear-sighted examination of fantasy, this film features an excellent cast of women who approach their life, work and relationships with street-smart humour. It is the men around them who find themselves ultimately more repressed by the guilt and shame with which they shroud their sexual fantasies. The film also intelligently and sharply explores the contradictions of race and performance, examining how for an African-American woman the “invisibility” of voice and the phone allows for a greater opportunity of expression than when roles are circumscribed by the hue of her skin colour. This is a vibrant, entertaining and poignant film. Features cameo appearances by Madonna, Quentin Tarantino, Debi Mazar, Naomi Campbell and Halle Berry.

results.title: Girl's sports: on the right track
results.brief_description: Considers the limited opportunities available to women who want to compete in sporting events. Shows how these limitations are being replaced by new opportunities for women in a variety of competitive sports including track and field. Through a short history of track and field, with original archive footage of Babe Didrikson and Wilma Rudolf, the limitations that were available for women to compete in sporting events are shown. The experiences of three high-school girls - a cross-country runner, a shot putter and a broad jumper - shows the new opportunities available for girls today.

results.title: Girdle round the earth
results.creator_credit: Peter Bradford, World Wide Pictures, John Rowden and Bruce Sharman
results.brief_description: In 1820 Oersted discovered that a wire carrying an electric current has a magnetic filed which varies in accordance with the variations of the current. From this discovery the telegraph was developed; the Trans-Atlantic cable laid; the discovery of the telephone; and the advent of the radio. The cable and radio link should be supplemented by signals from satellites - thus the communication network is gradually encompassing the world.

results.title: Giraffe
results.brief_description: Shows without commentary the simple daily patterns of the giraffe at home in Tanzania. Examines through close ups its unusual shape and size: its markings, height and long legs.

results.title: Gippsland: Through the forest
results.brief_description: Provides a look at the life forms of the Gippsland forest area. Here the world’s tallest hardwood tree, the mountain ash, towers to a height of one hundred metres or more and provides food and shelter at all levels, from the forest floor where the lyrebird scavengers to the tree tops which provide launching pads for the spectacular sugar gliders. Shows also the impact of the area’s two enemies: fire and man, and shows a rare glimpse of the family life of Australia’s laughing bird, the kookaburra.

results.title: Gippsland: the high country
results.creator_credit: Dione Gilmour, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Part of “The World we share” series. Provides an exploration of the mountains in Gippsland through the changing seasons. Shows how the long winter surprisingly sustains a complex network of life underneath the snow. The brief spring and summer bring a rush of life witnessed in the vocal battle of frogs over territory, the birth of a butterfly, the migration of cockatoos and the life style of the burramy. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Gippsland: open to the sea
results.creator_credit: Dione Gilmour, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Part of “The World we share” series. Provides a study of life that abounds in the lake area in Gippsland. Shows the microscopic life in the waters of the lakes. Also notes the animals and birds that inhabit the shores such as the sea eagles that fish the lakes and the ant lion and the digger wasp that make their homes in the lake’s sandy shores. The mysterious moss ball swamps near the lakes are also looked at. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: Gippsland: Down river
results.brief_description: Shows how the floods that bring disaster to man in the Gippsland area play a key area play a key role in the natural cycle of the plant and animal life to be found there. However in the remote swamps and wetlands of the area, the cycle is threatened by man’s activities further upstream.
